note.p: Lewis M. Hall was a law enforcement officer and public official in Mississippi during the Reconstruction official.

His year and location of birth are unclear, as Hall first appears in the public record in Mississippi in 1864, during federal occupation of Vicksburg. He apparently served as an agent of the Freedmen’s Bureau in that city, receiving property in the commission of the bureaur’s work. At the end of the Civil War, Hall advertised a merchant business, in which he imported northern goods for sale in Vicksburg. By the late 1860s, however, he had turned to public office, serving as Justice of the Peace and a notary public in Vicksburg.

In 1870, Hall received an appointment by Governor James L. Alcorn as chief detective in command of a state secret service unit. Hall led a group of seven detectives, two of whom were African American, given sweeping authority by the governor to investigate and arrest people suspected of committing violent crimes during a period of intense political and racial tensions. The unit lasted only one year before it lost funding and dissolved in the face of criticism by Alcorn’s political opponents. Hall continued to work in law enforcement, serving as sheriff of Warren County, as marshal in Vicksburg, and then as the city’s chief of police in the early 1870s. In early 1874, he was arrested for taking bribes to allow gambling establishments to remain in the community. Despite these charges, he was a Republican candidate for mayor of Vicksburg that same year, but died of illness on June 23, 1874.

(The Vicksburg Herald, Vicksburg, MS, January 9, 1866, and October 10, 1869; The Vicksburg Daily Times, Vicksburg, MS, January 13, 1872; The Vicksburg Herald, Vicksburg, MS, August 4, 1874; Warren County, Mississippi, Probate Court Docket, 1810-1940; William T. Blain, “Challenge to the Lawless: The Mississippi Secret Service, 1870-1871,” The Mississippi Quarterly, Vol. 31, No. 2 [Spring 1978], pp. 229-240; Records of the Field Offices for the State of Mississippi, Bureau of Refugeees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands, 1865-1872; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, June 25, 1874; Newton Weekly Ledger, Newton, MS, March 12, 1874; Lucas Somers, “Gov. Alcorn’s Secret Service Infiltrates the Ku Klux Klan – Part 1,” May 20, 2022, CWRGM Blog)

Located in Warren County, Mississippi, Vicksburg was founded under the name Fort Nogales as early as 1790 in what was then unincorporated territory. In 1798, upon creation of Mississippi Territory, it was renamed Walnut Hills. On April 1, 1799, Walnut Hills became part of the newly created Pickering County (later renamed Jefferson County on January 10, 1802), until the creation of Claiborne County on January 26, 1802. It then became part of its current county of Warren on December 21, 1809. Upon its incorporation on January 29th, 1825, it was renamed Vicksburg. Vicksburg became the county seat in 1836 and remains today. (Rowland, Mississippi, 858; Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

div.p:
The State of Mississippi
City of Vicksburg

Personally appeared before me the un-dersigned Clerk of the City of Vicksburg John Rainwater a Captain of Police in said City who being duly sworn deposeth and saist. Thus having received orders from Hon J C Webber Mayor to arrest all Gamblers and Keepers of Gaming homes in the City of Vicksburg and to bring the same before the City Judge. I proceeded to the City Hall and made affidavit against such as I had reason to believe were owners or keepers of gaming houses, before the City Clerk who issued the same day which was on or about February 21st 1871 Warrants for their arrest.

Proceeding with warrants in my hands for the arrest of four or five gaming house keepers I met Mr L. M Hall City Mar-shal and told him that I was going to arrest the Gamblers that night when he told me to let the gamblers alone. I informed him that I had made affidavits

against them and that I had warrants in my hands for their arrest. Mr Hall then told me I had no business to do it without orders from him. I told him I had orders from the Mayor. When Mr Hall said Mayor Webber had nothing to do with the police force. and that I should receive no orders from any one but him. And that I should arrest no more gamblers unless I received orders from him to do so.
[Deponent?] further states that he has never since that time received any orders from the Said L M Hull City Marshal to arrest any one for gaming or keeping a gaming house.

Sworn to and subscribed
before me this 23rd day of
March A. D. 1871

Jos W. Short
City Clerk of Vicksburg Miss

The State of Mississippi
City of Vicksburg
Personally appeared before me the un-dersigned Clerk of the City of Vicksburg Leopold Wise a Special Policeman of said City who being duly sworn deposeth and says, That he has received orders ^from Mayor Webber^ on several occasions to arrest all Gamblers and Keepers of gaming houses and have them brought before the City Court. I ^[?]^ have also heard him order John Rainwater Captain of the police to see that no one is allowed to keep a gam-ing house in the City but to close all such houses and arrest the occupants. I know that on or about the 22nd day of February /71 Mr Rainwater in pursuance of orders received from Hon J C Webber Mayor caused the arrest of several Gamblers who was fined by Judge R Barnett of the City Court
Sworn to and subscribed before me this 23 day of March 1871

Jos W. Short
City Clerk of Vicksburg

Vicksburg Miss—
Statement of Jno Rainwater Capt Police & L. Wise Special Policeman
Order of arrest of arrest of Gam-blers from the Mayor to City Marshal
